Headline: Top 1% Marketing Talent in Kochi (Under 30) | Helping Tech Teams in Enterprises make RRATIONAL decisions in Marketing + Growth | B2B Contractor | Brand Consultant | GTM | Generalist at Large | Service Exports
Comment:
That end part is so true, very few people admit it,

"What gets measured, can also be gamed"

I think the highly competitive nature in India leads you to this path eventually, especially if you stay in the game too long, rigidly (without pivoting)

I honestly think that 100% honest people don't prosper in India, the game is such,

Or you have to be around roughly 400% better (than the competition) to be honest and succeed.

People in India succeed despite their honesty, never because of it, 

there is a huge misalignment in incentives and it's so hard to fix.

Because so many people are fighting against hunger and basic sustenance. They never want to innately be dishonest, but the high competition (& population) often makes them distort a few facts here and there. Especially while playing high volume games.

Honesty and transparency is a big luxury (and premium), in the end.
